intro: Cereus cruciformis, commonly known as the four-angled cactus, is a species native to the arid regions of South America. It is characterized by its tall, cylindrical stems that are ribbed and often have a four-angled cross-section. The plant produces striking white flowers that bloom at night, typically during the warmer months. It is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments with minimal water requirements. Its structure and blooming pattern make it a popular choice for cactus enthusiasts and xeriscaping.
